Composite Signals Report

Generated on: December 10, 2025 at 08:09 AM

Overarching Recommendation

Overarching Recommendation: Macroeconomic Synthesis & Narrative

As of: 2025-12-31 | Coverage: 2024-12-31 to 2025-12-31

Scope reflects all signals provided in this run; structure is invariant to new or removed inputs.

1) Executive Summary (≤ 120 words)

The macroeconomic outlook is shifting towards a disinflationary slowdown, supported by significant liquidity but challenged by weakening real activity. Inflation signals point to a cooling trend, with market expectations remaining stable. Labor market indicators broadly suggest increasing slack and decelerating dynamism. Critically, strong central bank liquidity injections are providing a key counter-balance. However, elevated financial stress persists despite normalizing market volatility, with credit spreads at historically tight levels but showing some recent upward pressure. The yield curve steepening may reflect rising term premium or cautious future growth expectations, necessitating a careful, neutral-to-bearish stance.

  • Disinflationary Slowdown
  • Liquidity-Supported Fragility
  • Cautious / Neutral-to-Bearish

3) Dominant Themes

  • Persistent disinflationary trends are evident across broad measures and moderating wage growth (per US Inflation, Wage Growth).
  • Labor market deterioration, marked by rising slack and decelerating dynamism, points to underlying economic softening (per Labor Turnover, Employment Composition).
  • Substantial central bank liquidity continues to underpin financial markets, mitigating a sharper economic downturn (per Fed Liquidity, M2 Money Supply).
  • Financial system fragilities persist as stress indicators remain elevated despite stable headline volatility (per Financial Stress Index, Market Volatility).
  • Tight credit spreads face upward pressure, hinting at increasing risk concerns amid economic deceleration (per Credit Spread, Financial Stress Index).

4) Cross-Signal Interactions

Explain how signals reinforce or offset each other. Prioritize causal or historically reliable linkages.

  • Strong Fed Liquidity eases financial conditions, contributing to "COOL" US Inflation and stable MIIE.
  • Weak Labor Turnover and Bearish Consumer Sentiment signal deteriorating demand despite Bullish Durable Goods orders.
  • Tight Credit Spreads against elevated Financial Stress indicate a fragile market susceptible to adverse shifts.
  • A "Weakening" USD (per USD Index) and expanding liquidity may offer some resilience against domestic slowdowns.

5) Regime Assessment

Current Regime: Disinflationary Slowdown with Liquidity Support

Evidence: "COOL" US Inflation and moderating wage growth indicate disinflation. Broad weakening in labor market signals (Employment Composition, Job Flows, Weekly Hours, Labor Turnover) alongside deeply "Bearish" Consumer Sentiment point to a slowdown. This is being significantly offset by "Expansionary" Fed Liquidity and "Bullish" M2 Money Supply.

Historical Analogue(s): This environment shares characteristics with periods of mid-to-late cycle slowdowns where central bank actions (or the after-effects of past actions like RRP unwind) provide liquidity, preventing an immediate hard landing but failing to ignite strong growth.

6) Asset-Class Implications (Evidence-Linked)

  • Equities: Neutral-to-Underweight, favoring quality/defensive sectors. Weakening labor dynamics (Labor Turnover) and Bearish Consumer Sentiment suggest growth headwinds, partly offset by strong liquidity (Fed Liquidity).
  • Bonds/Duration: Overweight duration. "COOL" US Inflation and moderating Wage Growth, alongside a steepening yield curve (Treasury Yield Curve), support lower policy rates or flight to safety.
  • Credit: Neutral-to-Underweight. Elevated Financial Stress and recent upward pressure in High Yield spreads (Credit Spread) indicate rising risk despite current tight levels.
  • FX (USD): Underweight USD. The "Weakening" USD Index in an "Expansionary" liquidity environment typically reflects global easing conditions, reducing its appeal.
  • Commodities/Metals: Neutral Industrial Metals, Overweight Precious Metals. Weak industrial production (Industrial Production) and slowing growth tilt against industrial commodities, while disinflation and stress (US Inflation, Financial Stress) favor gold.
  • Other (if applicable): No specific tilt can be clearly inferred for other asset classes based solely on the provided signals.

State directional tilts (e.g., OW/UW/Neutral) only where the evidence is clear; otherwise say “no tilt.”

8) Risk Checks & Contradictions

  • "NORMAL" Market Volatility vs. "Bearish" Financial Stress suggests hidden systemic fragilities despite calm equity-linked measures.
  • Historically tight Credit Spreads (favorable) conflict with high Financial Stress, indicating potential mispricing or impending widening.
  • Strong Liquidity (Fed Liquidity, M2) seems disconnected from weakening real economic indicators (Labor Turnover, Consumer Sentiment).
  • Bullish Durable Goods orders stand out against general growth and labor market weakening, signaling mixed underlying demand.
  • "COOL" US Inflation but "STABLE" Market-Implied Inflation Expectations imply markets are not fully pricing a deep deflationary scenario.

9) Confidence & Data Quality

Confidence Score (0–100): 70

Drivers of Confidence: Good coverage across major macroeconomic pillars, with clear trends in inflation, labor market deceleration, and liquidity expansion. Z-scores and regimes provide quantifiable strength.

Data Gaps/Latency: Job Flows Labor signal is lagging (latest Dec 2024). Wage Pressure Signal (within Wage Growth) is also somewhat lagged (latest Apr 2025). M2 signal for Fed Liquidity Composite relies on Oct 2025 data, creating a slight lag in the composite itself. An internal inconsistency was noted where the USD Index narrative states "Weakening" while the corresponding dataframe `USD_Signal` column shows "Bullish" for 2025-12-01. No explicit sovereign credit signal was provided.
